facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 55 of 1955 in Criminal Appellate Jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 55 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated August 26, 1957 of Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1208 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 26, 1957, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1208 of 1955,

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and order dated March 31, 1955 of Sessions Judge, Baroda in Criminal Appeal No. 13 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated March 31, 1955, of the Sessions Judge, Baroda, in Criminal Appeal No. 13 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by SARKAR, J. on April 19, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. April 19. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR, J.-

facts.text: Appellant and two others convicted by Magistrate under s. 420 read with ss. 511 and 34 IPC, sentenced to RI 12 months, fine Rs. 500, default RI 4 months.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and two others were companyvicted by a Magistrate under s. 420 read with ss. 511 and 34 of the Indian Penal Code and each was sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for 12 months and a fine of Rs. 500

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted the accused persons on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the accused persons were acquitted by a Sessions Judge.

facts.text: State appealed to Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State then appealed to the High Court at Bombay

facts.text: Bombay High Court set aside Sessions Judge's acquittal and restored Magistrate's order.

anchor.surface_text: and the High Court set aside the order of acquittal and restored the order passed by the learned Magistrate.

facts.text: Accused No. 1 (appellant) appealed against High Court order to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Accused No. 1 alone has appealed against the order of the High Court to this Court.

facts.text: Three accused approached Ramanlal; third accused told him accused Nos. 1 and 2 proficient in duplicating currency numbers and prepared to do it for him.

anchor.surface_text: The three accused persons approached one Ramanlal and the third accused told Ramanlal that accused Nos. 1 and 2 were proficient in duplicating currency numberes and they were prepared to do it for Ranlanal who should take advantage of the offer.

facts.text: Third accused asked Ramanlal to think over and promised to come again.

anchor.surface_text: The third accused then asked Ranianlal to think over the matter and promised to companye again.

facts.text: Ramanlal told friend Champaklal (complainant), they decided to trap accused disbelieving their power to duplicate numbers.

anchor.surface_text: Ramanlal later mentioned this matter to his friend Champaklal, the companyplainant, and the two decided to trap the accused persons disbelieving their professed power to du- plicate numberes.

facts.text: Third accused came again and met Ramanlal and Champaklal.

anchor.surface_text: The third accused again came as promised and met Rtamanlal and Champaklal.

facts.text: Champaklal promised currency numbers for Rs. 20,000 for duplicating and a date was fixed.

anchor.surface_text: Champaklal promised to find currency numberes for Rs. 20,000 for duplicating and a date was fixed when it was to be done.

facts.text: Ramanlal and Champaklal informed the police.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Ramanlal and Champaklal informed the police.

facts.text: Police hid in Ramanlal's house where duplicating was fixed to be done.

anchor.surface_text: The police hid themselves in the house of Ramanlal where it had been fixed with the accused that the duplicating would be done.

facts.text: Three accused arrived at Ramanlal's house.

anchor.surface_text: The three accused arrived duly.

facts.text: Second accused spread bottles, blank papers etc. on a carpet.

anchor.surface_text: The second accused spread bottles, blank papers, etc., on a carpet

facts.text: First accused (appellant) asked Champaklal to produce the currency numbers.

anchor.surface_text: and the first accused, the appellant, asked Champaklal to produce the currency numberes.

facts.text: Champaklal carried bag supposed to contain Rs. 20,000 currency notes, took out two Rs. 100 notes and gave to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Champaklal who was carrying a bag supposed to companytain the promised currency numberes worth Rs. 20,000, took out two currency numberes of Rs. 100 each from the bag and gave them to the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant took the Rs. 200 money from Champaklal.

anchor.surface_text: As soon as the appellant bad taken the money,

facts.text: Champaklal gave pre-arranged signal, police arrested all accused.

anchor.surface_text: Champaklal gave the pre-arranged signal and the police came into the room and arrested all the accused persons.

facts.text: Accused prosecuted for attempt to cheat on complaint by Champaklal.

anchor.surface_text: They were thereafter prosecuted for the offence of an attempt to cheat upon a companyplaint lodged by Champaklal with the result already mentioned.

facts.text: Courts below found representation made to Champaklal, finding supported by evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The Courts below however found that such a representation had been made and we think that the finding is clearly supported by the evidence on record.

facts.text: Learned advocate for appellant argued no evidence of representation to Champaklal.

anchor.surface_text: First it was said that the charge was for an attempt to cheat Champaklal but there was numberevidence to -,how that any representation bad been made by anyone to Champaklal.

facts.text: Court found false representation made and Rs. 200 obtained from Champaklal.

anchor.surface_text: A fals representation had been made and a sum of Rs. 200 had been obtained from Champaklal.

facts.text: Complainant not deceived, never believed accused could duplicate currency numbers, feigned belief to trap.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the companyplainant bad number been taken in. He had never believed that the accused companyld actually duplicate currency numberes. He feigned belief only in order to trap the accused.

facts.text: Appellant argued no attempt to cheat because complainant not deceived.

anchor.surface_text: The last point argued was that there was numberattempt to cheat because the companyplainant bad number been deceived.

concepts.interpretation: Applied along with ss.420 and 511 for conviction of multiple accused for common acts in the offence.

concepts.unlisted_description: Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property

anchor.surface_text: ss. 511 and 34 of the Indian Penal Code

concepts.unlisted_description: Punishment for attempt to commit offence

anchor.surface_text: s. 511 of the Indian Penal Code.

concepts.interpretation: Acts done towards commission of offence, such as making false representation and obtaining property, constitute attempt under s.511, beyond mere preparation.
concepts.unlisted_description: Punishment for attempt to commit offence

anchor.surface_text: s. 420 of the Indian Penal Code.

concepts.interpretation: Ingredients include making of false representation and delivery of property, both of which occurred here.
concepts.unlisted_description: Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property

anchor.surface_text: They were thereafter prosecuted for the offence of an attempt to cheat upon a complaint lodged by Champaklal with the result already mentioned.

concepts.interpretation: False representation made to induce delivery of property; actual deception not required for attempt.

anchor.surface_text: A fals representation had been made and a sum of Rs. 200 had been obtained from Champaklal.

concepts.interpretation: Distinguished from preparation; involves proximate acts like inducement and delivery; failure (no deception) irrelevant for attempt offence.

anchor.surface_text: The last point argued was that there was noattempt to cheat because the complainant had no been deceived.

concepts.interpretation: Attempt complete despite no actual deception by complainant who feigned belief to trap accused.

anchor.surface_text: The next point taken was that there had been numberattempt to companymit the offence of cheating but only a preparation to companymit that offence which was number punishable.

arguments.court_reasoning: False representation made and Rs. 200 obtained are acts towards commission within s. 511 IPC as they are ingredients of s. 420 IPC offence of cheating

arguments.claim: There was no attempt to cheat because the complainant had not been deceived

anchor.surface_text: The last point argued was that there was numberattempt to cheat because the companyplainant bad number been deceived.

arguments.court_reasoning: Complainant feigned belief to trap accused but accused attempted to cheat and failure to deceive is irrelevant for attempt offence

arguments.claim: A representation had been made to Champaklal and the finding of lower courts is supported by evidence

anchor.surface_text: The Courts below however found that such a representation had been made and we think that the finding is clearly supported by the evidence on record.

arguments.claim: Acts constituted an attempt to cheat under ss. 420/511 IPC, not mere preparation, as false representation made and property obtained which are ingredients of cheating

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us clear that an attempt to companymit the offence bad actually been made. A fals representation had been made and a sum of Rs. 200 had been obtained from Champaklal. These clearly are acts done towards the companymission of the offence within the meaning of s. 511 of the Indian Penal Code.

arguments.claim: Attempt to cheat complete despite no actual deception of complainant

anchor.surface_text: That however clearly makes numberdifference so far as an attempt to cheat is companycerned. The accused had attempted to cheat the companyplainant. That they had failed in their attempt is irrelevant in companysidering whether they had companymitted the offence of attempting to cheat.

holdings.text: The Courts below found that a representation had been made to Champaklal and this finding is clearly supported by the evidence on record.

anchor.surface_text: The Courts below however found that such a representation had been made and we think that the finding is clearly supported by the evidence on record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts' factual finding on the making of the representation is affirmed as supported by evidence.

holdings.text: An attempt to commit the offence of cheating under s. 420 IPC had been made, as a false representation was made and Rs. 200 obtained from Champaklal, constituting acts towards commission within s. 511 IPC and ingredients of cheating; not mere preparation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: False representation and obtaining property are ingredients of s. 420 IPC offence and acts done towards commission under s. 511 IPC, going beyond preparation.

holdings.text: There was an attempt to cheat even though the complainant was not deceived, as failure to deceive is irrelevant for the offence of attempting to cheat.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Actual deception not required for attempt offence; accused's intent and acts suffice despite complainant's feigned belief.

anchor.surface_text: The last point argued was that there was numberattempt to cheat because the companyplainant had number been deceived. It is true that the companyplainant bad number been taken in. He had never believed that the accused companyld actually duplicate currency numberes. He feigned belief only in order to trap the accused. That however clearly makes numberdifference so far as an attempt to cheat is companycerned.

outcome.relief_summary: All arguments of the appellant rejected; conviction and sentence under s. 420 read with ss. 511 and 34 IPC upheld
